title: 108_s2351
content: The Act is titled the "Emergency Medical Services Support Act". There is a Federal Interagency Committee on Emergency Medical Services. The "Emergency Medical Services Support Act" establishes a Federal Interagency Committee on Emergency Medical Services (Interagency Committee on EMS) to improve coordination and support for emergency medical services. The committee consists of officials from various agencies including the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, the Department of Homeland Security, and the Department of Health and Human Services. The Department of Health and Human Services administers various agencies including the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services, and Indian Health Service. The Department of Homeland Security oversees the United States Fire Administration. The Federal Communications Commission's Wireless Telecommunications Bureau is headed by the Bureau Chief. Defense Department's Undersecretary for Personnel and Readiness is responsible for personnel matters. The Interagency Committee on EMS, under the Federal Communications Commission, coordinates with other federal agencies and state emergency medical services to ensure effective communication and response. The committee selects a chairperson annually from its members to lead its activities. The Interagency Committee on EMS, under the Federal Communications Commission, coordinates with federal agencies and state EMS to improve emergency medical services and 9-1-1 systems. This includes identifying needs, integrating EMS with homeland security, recommending new programs for improvement, and streamlining federal support processes. The Interagency Committee on EMS assists regional emergency medical services in setting priorities, advising on implementation of state EMS programs, and meets regularly as determined necessary. The Administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration provides administrative support to the Committee. The Interagency Committee on EMS prepares and submits annual reports to Congress on its activities, actions, and recommendations, including federal agency responsibilities and support for emergency medical services systems. The Federal Interagency Committee on Emergency Medical Services Advisory Council is established. The Federal Interagency Committee on Emergency Medical Services Advisory Council (Advisory Council) consists of up to 13 individuals with expertise in EMS, representing urban and rural areas and all sectors of the EMS community. The Council selects a chairperson annually and makes recommendations to the Interagency Committee on EMS on various topics. The Interagency Committee on EMS focuses on improving coordination and support of emergency medical services systems among Federal programs, developing a national EMS plan, setting standards and guidelines for EMS, conducting needs assessments for community-based EMS systems, creating grants for EMS improvement, and enhancing workforce development and training. The Advisory Council reviews and provides independent information or recommendations for the annual report of the Interagency Committee on EMS. They meet concurrently with the Committee and may hold separate meetings for public input. Compensation for Advisory Council members is also addressed. The Advisory Council members do not receive pay but are reimbursed for travel expenses. The Administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, with support from the Department of Homeland Security, provides administrative assistance to the Council.
